title: Multiplication Mastery
description: The most important unit in this course. Multiplication fact fluency is the single biggest predictor of math success in upper elementary and middle school. Students build from equal groups and arrays to automatic recall of facts through 12×12, learn the properties that make multiplication easier, master the multi-digit algorithm, solve comparison and multi-step word problems, and understand factors and multiples.
goals: Recall multiplication facts through 12×12 from memory within 3 seconds, understanding them as equal groups and arrays rather than counting
Apply the commutative, associative, distributive, zero, and identity properties to simplify multiplication and break apart difficult facts
Multiply multi-digit whole numbers using the area model, partial products, and the standard algorithm, estimating first to check reasonableness
Solve one-step and two-step word problems involving equal groups, arrays, and multiplicative comparison ('times as many')
Find all factor pairs of a number, identify numbers as prime or composite, list multiples, and apply factors and multiples to real-world grouping situations
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release for each skill: concept-intro → I Do → We Do → You Do before moving to the next skill
AI uses scaffold array as scope and worked-example bank — problems use concrete contexts familiar to 8-11 year olds: snacks, sports teams, classroom supplies, animals, and party planning
Emphasize recall over counting strategies — students should be building toward automatic retrieval of facts, not skip-counting on fingers
Use visual language (rows, columns, groups, arrays) so students can picture the multiplication even in text-based interaction
Connect each new skill to prior ones — properties help with facts, facts power the algorithm, the algorithm enables word problems, factors and multiples tie it all together

scaffold.title: Multiplication Facts Through 12×12
scaffold.content: Multiplication is a shortcut for adding equal groups. If you have 4 bags with 6 oranges in each bag, you could add 6 + 6 + 6 + 6, but it is much faster to just know that 4 × 6 = 24. You can also picture multiplication as an array — 4 rows with 6 in each row makes 24 objects total. The goal of this section is to know your facts through 12 × 12 so well that the answer pops into your head instantly, like knowing your own name. That kind of automatic recall frees up your brain for harder math later.
keyPoints: Multiplication means equal groups: 5 × 3 means 5 groups of 3 (or 3 groups of 5 — same answer!)
An array shows multiplication as rows and columns: 4 rows of 7 = 4 × 7 = 28
The times table goes from 1 × 1 all the way up to 12 × 12 = 144
The goal is automatic recall — you should know facts the way you know your address, without having to count or figure it out each time
Patterns help: any number × 1 = itself, any number × 0 = 0, the 2s are doubles, the 5s end in 0 or 5, the 9s digits always add to 9 (9, 18, 27, 36 …)
The trickiest facts for most students are 6 × 7, 6 × 8, 7 × 8, 8 × 8, and 7 × 12 — give these extra practice

examples.problem: A classroom has 7 tables. Each table has 8 crayons. How many crayons are there in all?
examples.solution:
This is 7 groups of 8.
7 × 8 = 56.
You can picture it as an array: 7 rows with 8 crayons in each row.
Answer: 56 crayons.

From memory: 9 × 6 = 54.
Quick check with the 9s pattern: the tens digit is one less than 6, so 5. The digits must add to 9, so 5 + 4 = 9. That gives 54. ✓
Answer: 54

examples.problem: There are 12 months in a year. If a library orders 11 new books every month, how many new books does the library get in a year?
examples.solution:
This is 12 groups of 11 (or 11 groups of 12 — same thing).
12 × 11 = 132.
One way to remember: 12 × 11 is just 12 × 10 + 12 × 1 = 120 + 12 = 132.
Answer: 132 new books.

problems.prompt: A baker puts 6 muffins on each tray. She fills 8 trays. How many muffins did she bake?
hints: This is 8 groups of 6. What is 8 × 6?
Think of it as an array: 8 rows with 6 in each row. Or use a fact you know — 8 × 6 is the same as 6 × 8.
problems.answer: 48 muffins. 8 × 6 = 48. Check: you can think of it as 8 × 5 = 40, plus 8 × 1 = 8, so 40 + 8 = 48. ✓

problems.prompt: What is 7 × 7?
hints: 7 × 7 is a square number — the same number times itself.
If you know 7 × 6 = 42, just add one more group of 7: 42 + 7.

problems.prompt: A soccer league has 9 teams. Each team has 12 players. How many players are in the league?
hints: This is 9 groups of 12, which is the same as 9 × 12.
Break it apart: 9 × 12 = 9 × 10 + 9 × 2.

problems.prompt: A parking lot has 11 rows of cars with 8 cars in each row. How many cars are in the lot?
problems.answer: 88 cars

problems.prompt: What is 12 × 12?
A camp has 6 cabins. Each cabin holds 7 campers. How many campers can the camp hold?
problems.answer: 42 campers

scaffold.title: Properties of Multiplication
scaffold.content: There are five handy rules — called properties — that make multiplication easier and more flexible. Once you know these, you can rearrange and break apart problems to make them simpler. For example, if you do not remember 6 × 8 right away, you can use the distributive property to think of it as 6 × 5 + 6 × 3, which gives 30 + 18 = 48. These properties are not just tricks — they are the reason mental math and the standard algorithm work.
keyPoints: Commutative property: the order does not matter. 3 × 7 = 7 × 3 = 21. If you know one, you know the other for free!
Associative property: when multiplying three numbers, you can group any two first. (2 × 3) × 4 = 2 × (3 × 4) = 24 either way.
Distributive property: you can break one factor into parts, multiply each part, and add the results. 6 × 8 = 6 × (5 + 3) = 6 × 5 + 6 × 3 = 30 + 18 = 48.
Zero property: any number times 0 equals 0. 500 × 0 = 0.
Identity property: any number times 1 equals that same number. 73 × 1 = 73.
The distributive property is the most powerful — it is the engine behind the multi-digit multiplication algorithm you will learn next

examples.problem: Use the commutative property: You know that 4 × 9 = 36. What is 9 × 4?
examples.solution:
The commutative property says the order does not change the answer.
Since 4 × 9 = 36, then 9 × 4 = 36 too.
Think of it this way: 4 rows of 9 and 9 rows of 4 both fill the same rectangle.
Answer: 36

examples.problem: Use the associative property to make this easier: 5 × 7 × 2
examples.solution:
You can multiply in any order. Pair the numbers that are easiest to multiply first.
5 × 2 = 10 (nice round number!)
Now multiply: 10 × 7 = 70.
Compare: doing (5 × 7) × 2 = 35 × 2 = 70 gives the same answer but is a little harder mentally.
Answer: 70

examples.problem: Use the distributive property to find 7 × 8.
examples.solution:
Break 8 into friendly parts: 8 = 5 + 3.
7 × 8 = 7 × (5 + 3) = 7 × 5 + 7 × 3 = 35 + 21 = 56.
Or break 7 into parts: 7 = 5 + 2.
7 × 8 = (5 + 2) × 8 = 5 × 8 + 2 × 8 = 40 + 16 = 56.
Either way the answer is the same.
Answer: 56

problems.prompt: Which property tells you that 8 × 5 and 5 × 8 give the same answer? What is the answer?
hints: Think about the property that says the order of the numbers does not change the product.
This is the commutative property. Now find the product: 8 × 5 = ?
problems.answer: The commutative property. 8 × 5 = 5 × 8 = 40.

problems.prompt: Use the distributive property to find 6 × 9. Break 9 into 10 − 1.
hints: The distributive property works with subtraction too: 6 × 9 = 6 × (10 − 1).
Now multiply each part: 6 × 10 = 60 and 6 × 1 = 6. Then subtract.
problems.answer: 54. Using the distributive property: 6 × (10 − 1) = 6 × 10 − 6 × 1 = 60 − 6 = 54. ✓

problems.prompt: Find 4 × 8 × 25 using the associative property. Hint: pair the two numbers that give a nice round product first.
hints: Look for a pair that makes a round number. What is 4 × 25?
4 × 25 = 100. Now multiply: 100 × 8.
problems.answer: 800. Group 4 × 25 first = 100, then 100 × 8 = 800. The associative property lets you regroup without changing the answer. ✓

problems.prompt: Use the distributive property to find 7 × 12. Break 12 into 10 + 2.
Name the property: 1 × 458 = 458.
problems.answer: The identity property of multiplication. Any number times 1 equals itself.

problems.prompt: Find 2 × 9 × 5 by regrouping with the associative property.

scaffold.title: Multi-Digit Multiplication
scaffold.content: When you multiply bigger numbers — like 36 × 24 — your single-digit facts still do all the heavy lifting, but you need an organized way to keep track. We will look at three methods that all give the same answer: the area model (great for seeing why it works), partial products (writes out every piece), and the standard algorithm (the fastest once you have it down). Before you start any multi-digit problem, always estimate first so you know roughly what the answer should be.
keyPoints: Estimate first: round each factor to the nearest ten and multiply. For 36 × 24, think 40 × 25 = 1,000. Your exact answer should be close to that.
Area model: draw a rectangle, split each side by place value (30 + 6 and 20 + 4), find the area of each smaller rectangle, then add them all up.
Partial products: write out each piece of the multiplication on its own line — 30 × 20, 30 × 4, 6 × 20, 6 × 4 — then add.
Standard algorithm: multiply by the ones digit first (write that row), then multiply by the tens digit (shift one place left), then add the rows.
When you multiply by tens, hundreds, etc., you are really using the distributive property — the algorithm just organizes the work.
Always compare your exact answer to your estimate. If they are far apart, double-check your work.

examples.solution:
Estimate: 50 × 3 = 150.
Standard algorithm:
  46
×  3
----
Step 1: 3 × 6 = 18. Write 8, carry the 1.
Step 2: 3 × 4 = 12, plus the carried 1 = 13. Write 13.
Result: 138.
Estimate check: 138 is close to 150. ✓
Answer: 138

Estimate: 30 × 30 = 900.
Break apart both numbers by place value:
  20 × 30 = 600
  20 ×  4 =  80
   7 × 30 = 210
   7 ×  4 =  28
Add all partial products: 600 + 80 + 210 + 28 = 918.
Estimate check: 918 is close to 900. ✓
Answer: 918

examples.problem: A school orders 158 notebooks for each of 6 classrooms. How many notebooks does the school order in all?
examples.solution:
Estimate: 160 × 6 = 960.
Standard algorithm:
  158
×   6
-----
Step 1: 6 × 8 = 48. Write 8, carry 4.
Step 2: 6 × 5 = 30, plus 4 = 34. Write 4, carry 3.
Step 3: 6 × 1 = 6, plus 3 = 9. Write 9.
Result: 948.
Estimate check: 948 is close to 960. ✓
Answer: 948 notebooks.

problems.prompt: Multiply 53 × 7. Estimate first, then use the standard algorithm.
hints: Estimate: round 53 to 50. What is 50 × 7?
Now do the algorithm: 7 × 3 = 21, write 1 and carry the 2. Then 7 × 5 = 35, plus the carried 2 = 37.
problems.answer: 371. Estimate: 50 × 7 = 350. Algorithm: 7 × 3 = 21 (write 1, carry 2). 7 × 5 = 35 + 2 = 37. Answer: 371. Close to the estimate of 350. ✓

problems.prompt: Multiply 38 × 25 using partial products.
hints: Break the numbers apart: 38 = 30 + 8 and 25 = 20 + 5. Multiply each pair of parts.
The four partial products are: 30 × 20, 30 × 5, 8 × 20, and 8 × 5. Add them all up.

problems.prompt: A farmer plants 215 seeds in each of 4 rows. How many seeds does the farmer plant?
hints: Estimate first: 200 × 4 = ?
Standard algorithm: start with 4 × 5 = 20 (write 0, carry 2). Then 4 × 1 = 4, plus 2 = 6. Then 4 × 2 = 8.
problems.answer: 860 seeds. Estimate: 200 × 4 = 800. Algorithm: 4 × 5 = 20 (write 0, carry 2), 4 × 1 = 4 + 2 = 6, 4 × 2 = 8. Answer: 860. Close to estimate. ✓

problems.prompt: Multiply 64 × 37.
A theater has 24 rows with 32 seats in each row. How many seats are in the theater?
problems.answer: 768 seats

problems.prompt: Multiply 305 × 8.

scaffold.title: Multiplication Word Problems
scaffold.content: Multiplication shows up in word problems in a few different ways. Sometimes you have equal groups ('5 boxes with 12 pencils each'). Sometimes you have an array ('8 rows of 9 tiles'). And sometimes you have a comparison ('Emma read 3 times as many books as Jake'). The phrase 'times as many' or 'times as much' is the big clue for comparison problems. Some problems have two steps — you might need to multiply and then add, or multiply two different things and compare. The key is to read carefully, figure out which type it is, and set up the multiplication before you calculate.
keyPoints: Equal groups: 'each,' 'every,' 'per' — multiply the number of groups by the size of each group
Array: 'rows and columns' — multiply rows × columns
Multiplicative comparison: 'times as many' or 'times as much' — one amount is a multiple of the other. If Jake has 4 books and Emma has 3 times as many, Emma has 3 × 4 = 12 books.
Two-step problems: read the whole problem first, plan both steps, then solve one at a time
Draw a simple picture or write a number sentence before computing — it helps you organize your thinking
Always label your answer with the correct units (books, dollars, miles, etc.) and ask: does this answer make sense?

examples.problem: A pet store has 8 fish tanks. Each tank holds 9 fish. How many fish are in the store?
examples.solution:
Type: equal groups.
Number of groups: 8 tanks.
Size of each group: 9 fish.
Number sentence: 8 × 9 = 72.
Answer: 72 fish.

examples.problem: Liam scored 6 points in a basketball game. Maya scored 4 times as many points as Liam. How many points did Maya score?
examples.solution:
Type: multiplicative comparison ('4 times as many').
Liam's points: 6.
Maya's points: 4 × 6 = 24.
Check: does 24 make sense as '4 times as many as 6'? Yes — 6 + 6 + 6 + 6 = 24. ✓
Answer: Maya scored 24 points.

examples.problem: A school buys 5 boxes of markers. Each box has 12 markers. They also buy 8 boxes of colored pencils with 10 pencils in each box. How many supplies did they buy in all?
examples.solution:
Type: two-step problem.
Step 1 — markers: 5 × 12 = 60 markers.
Step 2 — colored pencils: 8 × 10 = 80 colored pencils.
Step 3 — total: 60 + 80 = 140 supplies.
Answer: 140 supplies in all.

problems.prompt: A garden has 7 rows of tomato plants with 6 plants in each row. How many tomato plants are in the garden?
hints: This is an array problem. What multiplication sentence matches 7 rows of 6?
problems.answer: 42 tomato plants. 7 rows × 6 plants per row = 7 × 6 = 42. ✓

problems.prompt: Noah has 8 stickers. His sister has 5 times as many stickers as Noah. How many stickers does his sister have?
hints: The phrase 'times as many' tells you this is a comparison problem.
Multiply Noah's amount by 5: 5 × 8 = ?
problems.answer: 40 stickers. 5 × 8 = 40. His sister has 5 times as many as Noah's 8, which is 40. ✓

problems.prompt: A cafeteria serves lunch to 4 classes. Each class has 25 students. Each student gets 2 cartons of milk. How many cartons of milk does the cafeteria need?
hints: This is a two-step problem. First, find the total number of students: 4 × 25.
Then multiply the total number of students by 2 cartons each.
problems.answer: 200 cartons of milk. Step 1: 4 × 25 = 100 students. Step 2: 100 × 2 = 200 cartons. ✓

problems.prompt: A bookshelf has 6 shelves with 11 books on each shelf. How many books are on the bookshelf?
problems.answer: 66 books

problems.prompt: Carlos ran 3 miles on Saturday. His dad ran 4 times as far as Carlos. How far did his dad run?
problems.answer: 12 miles

problems.prompt: For a class party, 3 parents each bring 2 packs of juice boxes. Each pack has 8 juice boxes. How many juice boxes are there in all?
problems.answer: 48 juice boxes. (3 × 2 = 6 packs. 6 × 8 = 48.)

scaffold.title: Factors and Multiples
scaffold.content: Factors and multiples are two sides of the same coin. The factors of a number are the whole numbers that divide into it evenly. The multiples of a number are what you get when you multiply it by 1, 2, 3, 4, and so on. For example, the factors of 12 are 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, and 12 (they all go into 12 with no remainder). The multiples of 12 are 12, 24, 36, 48, and so on. A number with exactly two factors (1 and itself) is called prime. A number with more than two factors is called composite. Understanding factors and multiples helps with sharing, grouping, and — later — fractions.
keyPoints: Factors come in pairs: for 24, the factor pairs are (1, 24), (2, 12), (3, 8), (4, 6). That is all of them.
To find all factor pairs, start with 1 × the number, then try 2, 3, 4, ... Stop when the two factors meet or cross.
A prime number has exactly two factors: 1 and itself. Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13.
A composite number has more than two factors. Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10, 12.
The number 1 is neither prime nor composite — it has only one factor.
Multiples of a number go on forever: multiples of 5 are 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, ...
Real-world use: factors help you figure out how to split things into equal groups with nothing left over

examples.problem: Find all the factor pairs of 36.
examples.solution:
Start at 1 and work up:
1 × 36 = 36 ✓ → factor pair (1, 36)
2 × 18 = 36 ✓ → factor pair (2, 18)
3 × 12 = 36 ✓ → factor pair (3, 12)
4 × 9 = 36 ✓ → factor pair (4, 9)
5 × ? — 36 ÷ 5 = 7.2, not a whole number. Skip.
6 × 6 = 36 ✓ → factor pair (6, 6)
7 × ? — 36 ÷ 7 is not whole. Stop here because the next numbers will repeat pairs we already found.
All factors of 36: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 12, 18, 36.
36 is composite because it has more than two factors.

Check each number starting from 2:
17 ÷ 2 = 8.5 (not whole)
17 ÷ 3 = 5.67 (not whole)
17 ÷ 4 = 4.25 (not whole)
We can stop here because 5 × 5 = 25, which is already bigger than 17.
The only factors of 17 are 1 and 17.
Answer: 17 is prime.

examples.problem: You have 30 cupcakes to arrange in equal rows with none left over. List three different ways you could arrange them.
examples.solution:
Find factor pairs of 30:
1 × 30, 2 × 15, 3 × 10, 5 × 6.
Three possible arrangements:
• 2 rows of 15 cupcakes
• 3 rows of 10 cupcakes
• 5 rows of 6 cupcakes
(There are more — any factor pair works!)

problems.prompt: Find all the factor pairs of 28.
hints: Start with 1 × 28 and work up: try 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 ...
28 ÷ 2 = 14, 28 ÷ 3 is not a whole number, 28 ÷ 4 = 7. Since 5 × 5 = 25 < 28 and 6 × 5 = 30 > 28, check 5, 6, and 7 to be thorough.
problems.answer: Factor pairs: (1, 28), (2, 14), (4, 7). All factors of 28: 1, 2, 4, 7, 14, 28. Since it has more than two factors, 28 is composite. ✓

problems.prompt: Is 23 prime or composite? Explain how you know.
hints: Try dividing 23 by 2, 3, 4 ... Does any of them divide evenly?
You only need to check up to about 5 (because 5 × 5 = 25, which is already bigger than 23).
problems.answer: 23 is prime. 23 ÷ 2 = 11.5, 23 ÷ 3 = 7.67, 23 ÷ 4 = 5.75. None divide evenly. The only factors are 1 and 23. ✓

problems.prompt: List the first five multiples of 8. Then answer: is 52 a multiple of 8?
hints: To check if 52 is a multiple of 8, divide: 52 ÷ 8 = ?
problems.answer: First five multiples of 8: 8, 16, 24, 32, 40. Is 52 a multiple of 8? 52 ÷ 8 = 6.5 — not a whole number, so 52 is NOT a multiple of 8. ✓

problems.prompt: Find all the factors of 40.
A teacher has 18 students and wants to split them into equal groups with no one left out. List all the possible group sizes.
problems.answer: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, or 18 students per group (the factors of 18)

problems.prompt: Is 51 prime or composite? Prove it.
problems.answer: Composite. 51 ÷ 3 = 17, so 51 = 3 × 17. It has factors other than 1 and itself.
